qas.question: What does the personal copying exemption explicitly need?
What is an example of a country that the exemption was assumed?
When did the Court of Justice of the EU make a ruling about distinction?
In which country is downloading from a file-sharing network no longer legal?
What does the personal copying exemption explicitly not need?
What is an example of a country that the exemption wasn't assumed?
When didn't the Court of Justice of the EU make a ruling about distinction?
In which country is uploading from a file-sharing network no longer legal?
In which country is downloading from a file-sharing network always legal?

context: In some countries, the personal copying exemption explicitly requires that the content being copied <a0_0><b4_0>was obtained legitimately<b4_0/><a0_0/> – i.e., from authorized sources, not file-sharing networks. Other countries, such as the <a1_0><b5_0>Netherlands<b5_0/><a1_0/>, make no such distinction; the exemption there had been assumed, even by the government, to apply to any such copying, even from file-sharing networks. However, in <a2_0><b6_0>April 2014<b6_0/><a2_0/>, the Court of Justice of the European Union ruled that "national legislation which makes no distinction between private copies made from lawful sources and those made from counterfeited or pirated sources cannot be tolerated." Thus, in the <a3_0><b7_0><b8_0>Netherlands<b8_0/><b7_0/><a3_0/>, for example, downloading from file-sharing networks is no longer legal.
